sn54.10:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kimbilā in the Freshwater Mangrove Wood.
sn54.10:4.3: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Kimbila:
sn54.10:4.4: “Kimbila, how is samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
sn54.10:5.1: When he said this, Kimbila kept silent.
sn54.10:5.3: And for a third time, the Buddha said to him:
sn54.10:5.4: “How is samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
sn54.10:5.5: And a second time and a third time Kimbila kept silent.
sn54.10:6.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
sn54.10:6.3: Now is the time, Holy One!
sn54.10:6.4: Let the Buddha speak on samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
sn54.10:7.1: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention,
sn54.10:7.5: “Ānanda, how is samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?
sn54.10:7.6: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, sits down in the meditation posture, with their body erect, and establishes mindfulness right there.
sn54.10:7.7: Ever mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out. …
sn54.10:7.8: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
sn54.10:7.9: That’s how samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.
sn54.10:8.1: There’s a time when a mendicant, breathing in deep, knows: ‘I’m breathing in deep.’ Or breathing out deep they know: ‘I’m breathing out deep.’
sn54.10:8.2: Breathing in shallow they know: ‘I’m breathing in shallow.’ Or breathing out shallow they know: ‘I’m breathing out shallow.’
sn54.10:8.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
sn54.10:8.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
sn54.10:8.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:8.7: Because the breath is a certain aspect of the body, I say.
sn54.10:8.9: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:9.1: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’
sn54.10:9.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing bliss.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing bliss.’
sn54.10:9.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mental processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mental processes.’
sn54.10:9.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental processes.’
sn54.10:9.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:9.6: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:9.7: Because close focus on the breath is a certain aspect of feelings, I say.
sn54.10:9.9: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:10.1: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’
sn54.10:10.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out gladdening the mind.’
sn54.10:10.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in bringing the mind to samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out bringing the mind to samādhi.’
sn54.10:10.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’
sn54.10:10.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:10.7: Because there is no development of samādhi due to mindfulness of breathing for someone who is unmindful and lacks awareness, I say.
sn54.10:10.8: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:11.1: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’
sn54.10:11.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing fading away.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing fading away.’
sn54.10:11.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing cessation.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing cessation.’
sn54.10:11.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
sn54.10:11.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:11.6: Having seen with wisdom the giving up of desire and aversion, they watch closely over with equanimity.
sn54.10:11.7: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:12.1: Suppose there was a large heap of sand at the crossroads.
sn54.10:12.2: And a cart or chariot were to come by from the east,
sn54.10:12.5: or south and destroy that heap of sand.
sn54.10:12.6: In the same way, when a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body,
sn54.10:12.9: or principles, they destroy bad, unskillful qualities.”
